Kama Flow
Jan 23

Early bird catches the worm — What are the actual venture capital returns?

Working out an investment strategy for a VC basically involves three decisions: what type of companies to invest in, at which stage of its’ development to invest and, ultimately, when to exit. In order to do so VCs make assumptions on risk-reward based on their own performance, different sectors statistics and the expertise of the team behind the fund.

And they always are faced with the the big question. Should a VC invest early expecting a heftier multiplier at the exit or avoid risking close-out (which is much more likely during early development of a company) by investing at a later stage?

To answer the question we decided to use Crunchbase data as source of information and split the initial question into the following parts:

  • Based on close-out rate and valuation growth statistics, which stages are optimal to invest and exit for a VC?
  • Which niches deliver higher returns on a regular basis?
  • What are the differences of optimal investment stage and valuation growth for different niches?
  • How close-out rate changes stage-to-stage?

We have analyzed Crunchbase data on 4341 startup investment rounds, 37 IPO’s and 59 acquisitions to identify 696 startups that have received at least two investment rounds or at least one investment round and have secured an exit (37 of them exited through IPO’s and 59 were acquired). There were 2200 seed rounds, 748 angel rounds, 345 A-rounds, 190 B-rounds, 143 C-rounds, 114 D-rounds, 79 E-rounds, 40 F-rounds, 19 G-rounds, and 5 H-rounds. Most of those took place in the past 5 years, but some date back to 1977. The distribution of rounds in time is demonstrated in Figure 1.

From the data on those investment rounds and exits, we calculated “hypothetical” returns that an investor might have earned if they entered a startup in one round and exited in another. Each created data point contained information on what rounds the return could have been made between, the dates and dollar amounts of both rounds, as well as pre-money valuations of the company on those dates. Using that information, we computed annualized investment returns by dividing pre-money valuation of the latter round by the post-money valuation of the former, and then raising that figure to the power of the number years between the two rounds (which may be fractional).

We also recorded the ‘category’ assigned to the startup by Crunchbase together with the return data point. If multiple categories were assigned to the company, we created multiple data points. For example, if a startup had four investment rounds and was present in two categories, it would account for twelve data points (six for each possible hypothetical return, in each of the two categories).

We then sorted the data points by stage and category and calculated the geometric average return in every intersection, eliminating returns that were too high due to the short time (less than a few months) between rounds. From the 373 categories we selected 26 most relevant, while making sure that they cover most of the specter of startups and intersect as little as possible. We created a table where each column would represent an investment interval, such as seed-to-A or A-to-B, and each row would stand for one of the categories we have selected. Our findings are shown in Figure 2. The two-letter notation of stages are derived from the stages of the two rounds between which the returns could have taken place; S stands for seed or angel investment, A and B stand for rounds A and B, respectively, O stands for venture rounds C and above, I stands for IPO, and M stands for M&A. Naturally, due to the nature of our data, some of the cells were left blank.

To gather better insights from the table, we may look at different slices of the information. First, it might be interesting to see what categories have performed best in each of the investment intervals. Figure 3 shows the performance of startups between seed stages and A-rounds.

We then looked at the categories’ performance between seed stages (Figure 4). The distribution of returns there was much smoother, however there were 3 clear leaders, still: Hardware, Education and Transportation. It should be noted, however, that these seed-to-seed returns should be taken with a grain of salt, as company valuations at these early stages might not follow actual value created, but rather depend heavily on the founders’ negotiations with investors, whose estimations may or may not be quite rational.

If we then look at the hypothetical returns at later stages (Figure 6), performance distribution of 20 of the 23 categories is almost uniform, deviating only slightly from the average multiple of 1.6x. The two best-performing categories were Real Estate and Crowdfunding, with Video trailing behind the whole group at 0.4x.

When looking at the overall performance across all stages (Figure 7), we noticed the ranking was somewhat similar to the seed-to-A stage, where Transportation, Crowdfunding, and Real Estate were in the lead.

If we look at the average returns by investment interval (Figure 8), there is no definite pattern, but it is quite apparent that growth on later stages tends to be quite slower than early on.

Finally, we wanted to estimate the general popularity of categories and whether the best performing categories attracted the most investors. The number of hypothetical returns we generated in each category is given in Figure 9. As it turns, out, the popularity of startup categories with investors almost did not depend on the category’s overall performance.

It was found that at the seed-seed stage Transportation is the clear leader, as well as overall, however, this is mostly due to Uber’s rapid growth with a total of nine investment rounds. On later stages, however, Real Estate and Crowdfunding were in the lead. Fashion was the overall worst performer, coming in fourth last on both early and later stages, and last overall. Biotechnology was a breakthrough category, becoming second-worst on early stages and third best on later stages. This is not surprising, though, given the research-heavy, hit-or-miss nature of biotechnological companies.

It was quite peculiar that on every stage, the overall performance was about 3 times worse than the maximum performance.

Another finding was that M&A exits were on average more successful than IPO’s, although this was due to the fact that M&A’s were the preferred exit option on earlier stages (rounds A and B), and the returns on those stages were overall greater than the returns on later stages.

We also tried to estimate the optimal stage to invest in startups by calculating the geometric average returns between rounds from seed through round G, and also calculating the probabilities that a startup will die or become self-sustaining between any stage. We borrowed the data on probabilities of startups surviving or becoming self-sustaining from CB Insights’ research on the venture funnel (Figure 10).

Assuming that the average time interval between two consecutive investment rounds equals 15 months (the most common case) we got cross-round returns matrix (Figure 11).

As it turned out, the best possible return may be gained between seed and Round E (omitting survival rate). Moving on, we calculated survival probability matrix (Figure 12) from Venture Capital funnel by CB Insights.

Finally, multiplying extracted figures we estimated cross-rounds expected returns adjusted for survival rate (Figure 13).

  • As it turns out, the single best investment strategy, if you only pay attention to the stage of projects, is to invest in round A and exit in round B, and investments on earlier stages tend to outperform investments on later stages.
  • It was found that at the seed-seed stage Transportation is the clear leader, as well as overall, however, this is mostly due to Uber’s rapid growth with a total of nine investment rounds. On later stages, however, Real Estate and Crowdfunding were in the lead. Fashion was the overall worst performer, coming in fourth last on both early and later stages, and last overall. Biotechnology was a breakthrough category, becoming second-worst on early stages and third best on later stages. This is not surprising, though, given the research-heavy, hit-or-miss nature of biotechnological companies.
  • It was quite peculiar that on every stage, the overall performance was about 3 times worse than the maximum performance.
  • Another finding was that M&A exits were on average more successful than IPO’s, although this was due to the fact that M&A’s were the preferred exit option on earlier stages (rounds A and B), and the returns on those stages were overall greater than the returns on later stages.

The VC economy is an economy of outliers. The more extreme the outlier, the higher VC profitability. And every and all analysis of the accumulated data will be seriously influenced by several unique and historically important cases. Of course, an investment strategy depends on the types of projects and industries, but the principle “Early bird catches the worm” generally works.
